title: The Blessing of Unexpected Encounters
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock had a reputation. Not a good one. In our small town, he was known as the grumpiest soul alive. His face was perpetually set in a scowl, his words were sharp, and he seemed to take pleasure in finding fault with everything and everyone. The local kids whispered stories of a curse he'd put on anyone who dared to step on his lawn (which, admittedly, was meticulously manicured). Even the squirrels seemed to avoid his oak tree.

One crisp autumn morning, while volunteering at the community food bank, I saw Mr. Hemlock. He was shuffling slowly through the aisles, a worn shopping cart in tow. He looked even more frail and stooped than I remembered. As he reached for a can of soup, his hand trembled, and it slipped, clattering to the floor. I knelt to pick it up, and our eyes met. For a fleeting moment, I saw something flicker in his usually hardened gaze – a hint of vulnerability, perhaps even sadness.

Instead of simply handing him the can, I offered a genuine smile. "Rough morning?" I asked gently. He grunted in response, but didn't rebuff me outright. I helped him gather a few more items, offering encouraging words and sharing a brief story about my own clumsy mishap from the week before. As he wheeled away, he mumbled a barely audible, "Thank you." It was the first kind word I’d ever heard him speak.

Later that day, I couldn't shake the encounter. Mr. Hemlock’s reputation was well-earned, but perhaps there was more to his story than met the eye. Perhaps, beneath the layers of grumbling and negativity, there was a deep well of unmet needs, loneliness, or even unrecognized blessing. It struck me then that blessing isn’t just about receiving good things; it’s also about being a conduit of good, even (and especially) to those who seem least deserving. Blessing is about seeing the humanity, the potential for grace, in every single soul we encounter, and responding with compassion.
image_description: A single, brightly colored autumn leaf resting on a weathered, wooden bench in a quiet park.
insights: The idea of blessing those who may seem "unblessable" is central to Christian teaching. Jesus said, "Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, bless those who curse you, pray for those who mistreat you" (Luke 6:27-28). This isn't merely a nice sentiment; it's a radical call to action, challenging us to extend grace and kindness even when it’s difficult or uncomfortable. Romans 12:14 encourages believers to "Bless those who persecute you; bless and do not curse." This principle is a cornerstone of Christian witness, demonstrating the transformative power of love and forgiveness.
prayer: Heavenly Father, open my eyes to see the hidden needs and potential for blessing in every person I encounter, even those who seem difficult or unlovable. Help me to extend grace, kindness, and compassion, reflecting Your unconditional love. Give me the courage to be a conduit of Your blessing, even when it's uncomfortable or challenging. Remind me that everyone is worthy of love and that even the smallest act of kindness can make a profound difference. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Think about someone in your life who you find difficult to be around. How could you reframe your perspective to see them through the lens of compassion and blessing? What small act of kindness or generosity could you offer them this week?
